Zeke Wattles

About

Dublab

Related project: Indeterminacy
Category: Identity
Year: 2018

What It Is

Dublab is an online radio station based in Los Angeles. This is a transmedia identity system based on drawing with sound.

Why It Matters

I grew up in LA and have been a fan of Dublab since I was a teenager. I was a classically trained cellist who dreamed of being a bedroom beatmaker, and a huge fan of the LA beat scene, which Dublab played a big part in.

Dublab has been around since 1999 and is an independent online radio station with a raw, DIY, experimental ethos &emdash; an experimental platform for the growth of music, art, culture, and everything in between.


Drawing with Sound

I created a unique tool for making posters and large-scale installations through sound synthesis. The Processing program works like a feedback loop: images are translated to sound, sound is visualized on the oscilloscope, then that sound is filtered, which affects the image again. It’s like a synthesizer for visuals. The code is based on the open source XYscope library.


The Processing sketch used to generate poster linework.
A phone running TouchOSC controls the filter value for the sound image.

Custom Typefaces

Two typefaces were developed for Dublab based around sound: DB Data Mono is a true monospace revival of Data70 in sine- and square wave variants; DB Circuit Mono is a connected digital “script” based on the way type is rendered on oscilloscopes.

DB Circuit Mono
DB Data Mono

In Conversation

Talking to Mark, he became a partner in the process. I took the initiative to talk to the client directly and asked, what would be useful to you? He mentioned that Dublab had a large archive of interviews with musicians that he felt was important to preserve. I proposed a print version. I used the same text tool I built for Indeterminacy to create chapter breaks, and DB Circuit Mono for the cover typography. The first edition is a conversation with Van Dyke Parks.
